questions.text: A 31-year-old man, who was hospitalized for substance-induced psychosis two days ago, has had episodic neck stiffness and pain for the past 8 hours. These episodes last for approximately 25 minutes and are accompanied by his neck rotating to the right. During the last episode, he was able to relieve the stiffness by lightly touching his jaw. He has received six doses of haloperidol for auditory hallucinations since his admission. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Examination shows a flexed neck rotated to the right. The neck is rigid with limited range of motion. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia manifests with painful torticollis (as seen here), opisthotonus, oculogyric crisis, trismus, tongue spasm, and/or laryngospasm. Risk factors include male sex and young age. This condition's pathophysiology is incompletely understood but an imbalance between dopaminergic activity in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia (due to D2 receptor antagonism by the antipsychotic) and cholinergic transmission in the striatum is thought to play a role. A centrally acting anticholinergic drug such as benztropine or diphenhydramine is the first-line treatment for neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia (see “Overview of extrapyramidal symptoms” table).

The role of cholinergic transmission in the pathophysiology of neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia is also supported by the observation that the risk of acute dystonia is lower with low-potency typical antipsychotics, which have an anticholinergic effect and a weaker antidopaminergic effect when compared with high-potency typical antipsychotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy can be used as an adjunctive treatment for this patient's condition. However, highly effective, well-tolerated pharmacotherapy would be the first-line intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant used to treat malignant hyperthermia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and (severe) chronic spasticity resulting from upper motor neuron damage (e.g., stroke, multiple sclerosis). Although the patient suffers from spasticity in his neck, the condition is acute and not chronic. In addition, since dantrolene may also cause psychiatric side effects (e.g., depression, confusion, insomnia), it should be given with caution in patients with a history of psychiatric symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Baclofen is a GABA receptor agonist commonly used as a muscle relaxant to treat spasticity. However, it shows little effect in the treatment of secondary dystonia (e.g., medication-induced acute dystonia) and would only be indicated after other preferred treatments have failed. Baclofen is usually used for treating primary dystonia (idiopathic, hereditary) and is more effective in children and adolescents than in adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the first-line treatment for akathisia, which is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic drugs. While this patient is at risk for akathisia, it is characterized by restlessness, fidgeting, and/or pacing. Instead, this patient's cervical muscle spasms are characteristic of another extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics.
questions.hint: The repeated episodes of painful neck stiffness are suggestive of acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect that typically occurs within a few days of initiating or increasing the dose of a high-potency typical antipsychotic (e.g., haloperidol).

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a dry mouth and blurred vision for the past 30 minutes. Prior to this, he was on a road trip and started to feel nauseous, dizzy, and fatigued, so his friend gave him a drug that had helped in the past. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and dilated pupils. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Administration of which of the following drugs is most likely to cause a similar adverse reaction in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic that, like other agents in its class, causes miosis. It does not cause anticholinergic toxicity.

B) CORRECT:

Oxybutynin is a muscarinic antagonist that treats overactive bladder incontinence. Like other muscarinic antagonists, such as scopolamine, it has adverse anticholinergic effects including this patient's dry mucous membranes and mydriasis resulting from a lack of specificity to its target tissue. Toxicity with anticholinergic agents (causing anticholinergic syndrome) is treated with physostigmine.

C) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is an antiemetic that also functions as a promotility agent and acts as both a dopamine receptor antagonist and a serotonin receptor antagonist. Adverse effects include parkinsonism and diarrhea, but it does not cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Pilocarpine is a direct parasympathomimetic that treats glaucoma and Sjögren syndrome. This drug would cause cholinergic symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, urination, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia, neuromuscular excitation, lacrimation, sweating, and salivation (“DUMBBELSS” mnemonic)), not the mydriasis and dry mouth experienced by this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic drug that can cause mydriasis, as seen in this patient. However, it does not cause anticholinergic toxicity.

F) INCORRECT:

Loratadine is a second-generation H1 antihistamine that, unlike its first-generation counterparts, does not cause significant anticholinergic toxicity.
questions.hint: This patient likely received a scopolamine patch for treatment of his motion sickness and now experiences dry mouth and blurred vision as a result of its anticholinergic effects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his sister for the evaluation of progressive drowsiness and confusion over the past 6 hours. The patient is lethargic and unable to answer questions. His sister says that he has a history of illicit drug use. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, dry skin and dry mucous membranes. The pupils are dilated. The abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are hypoactive. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Intoxication with which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intoxication with phencyclidine, which is also referred to as “angel dust,” is characterized by violent and/or psychotic behavior but can in some cases also manifest with CNS depression and sedation. Additional clinical features of toxicity include increased pain tolerance, ataxia, dysarthria, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Intoxication with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors causes serotonin syndrome, which can manifest with delirium and/or confusion, hyperthermia, tachycardia, and mydriasis. However, serotonin syndrome causes diaphoresis and diarrhea, rather than the dry skin and dry mucous membranes seen here. Moreover, other findings commonly seen in serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension and nausea, are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Cannabis intoxication can manifest with mild tachycardia, dry mouth, and mydriasis with conjunctival injection. However, other typical findings, such as hyperemesis, dysphoria, anxiety, panic, and increased blood pressure are absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Cocaine intoxication may cause mydriasis and tachycardia. However, the condition usually manifests with agitation and diaphoresis, as opposed to the sedation and dry skin seen in this patient. Other findings typically seen in cocaine intoxication, such as hypertension, are absent.

E) INCORRECT:

Opioid intoxication may lead to altered mental status, which is consistent with this patient's confusion and sedation. Additionally, opioid intoxication can manifest with hypoactive bowel sounds. However, opioid toxicity causes miosis rather than mydriasis. Moreover, other findings commonly seen in opioid intoxication, such as respiratory depression, are absent.

F) INCORRECT:

Cyanide intoxication can manifest with confusion (and in severe cases, seizure or coma), vertigo, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Patients are usually initially hypertensive and tachycardic, but then become hypotensive and bradycardic. This patient's mydriasis and dry, warm skin are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Amphetamine intoxication can manifest with constipation, mydriasis, and tachycardia. While severe cases of amphetamine toxicity may cause coma, patients are usually agitated or psychotic. Additionally, the condition usually manifests with diaphoresis, as opposed to the dry skin seen in this patient.

H) INCORRECT:

Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning can manifest with a variety of clinical features, depending on the blood level concentrations. CO poisoning can lead to confusion and lethargy. However, other common symptoms such as headache, malaise, dizziness, and the typical cherry-red appearance of the lips are absent in this patient. In severe cases, CO poisoning can cause myocardial infarction and respiratory failure.

I) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is characteristic of antihistamine toxicity, which is most commonly caused by an overdose of first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine). The CNS effects of sedation and confusion are mediated by H1 histamine receptors, while dry skin, dry mucous membranes, mydriasis, hyperthermia, tachycardia, and reduced bowel sounds are due to anticholinergic effects. Further complications of antihistamine toxicity include cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and seizures. Management includes close monitoring, supportive therapy, and, in severe cases, administration of an anticholinergic antidote.

Second-generation antihistamines have less of a sedative effect than first-generation antihistamines because of their limited CNS activity.
questions.hint: This patient should be treated with physostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his neighbor 2 hours after ingesting an unknown substance in a suicide attempt. He is confused and unable to provide further history. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. His skin is dry. Pupils are 12 mm and minimally reactive to light. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sodium bicarbonate is used for the treatment of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose. Overdose with certain TCAs, such as amitriptyline, can manifest almost identically to an anticholinergic overdose, but with the additional finding of ECG abnormalities (e.g., QT prolongation, arrhythmias).

B) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used for the rapid reversal of an opioid overdose. Although opioid overdose can also cause altered mental status, it also typically manifests with significantly reduced respiratory drive, bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, and miosis.

C) CORRECT:

Physostigmine is the first-line treatment for anticholinergic syndrome because it crosses the blood-brain barrier and rapidly enhances parasympathetic signaling. In addition to the classic findings seen in this patient, an overdose of anticholinergic drugs can also cause urinary retention, decreased bowel sounds, and erythematous skin (due to compensatory cutaneous vasodilation from hyperthermia). Use of physostigmine is usually only warranted in cases in which pure anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., overdose with atropine, benztropine) is suspected but can also be considered in patients with anticholinergic poisoning due to other agents (e.g., antihistamines) if they present with features of severe central anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., delirium). Physostigmine should be avoided in patients with tricyclic antidepressant overdose (TCA overdose) because of the risk of cardiac arrest. Ingestion of TCAs is unlikely in this patient as EKG findings are normal. Physostigmine should be administered carefully and patients should be monitored for cholinergic toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is used for the treatment of acetaminophen overdose to restore depleted hepatic glutathione, which is needed for the conjugation and excretion of the toxic acetaminophen metabolites. These patients typically present nonspecifically with nausea and vomiting before eventually progressing to liver failure (if not treated), in contrast to the acute, severe reaction seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is used in the treatment of beta blocker overdose, as it activates adenylate cyclase during depolarization, raising intracellular cAMP levels and improving cardiac contractility. Overdose with these drugs typically manifests with pronounced bradycardia, cardiogenic shock, altered mental status, wheezing (due to bronchoconstriction), and hypotension.

F) INCORRECT:

Flumazenil may be indicated for severe cases of benzodiazepine overdose, which could explain this patient's signs of central nervous system depression, such as decreased respiratory rate and altered mental status. However, benzodiazepine toxicity typically also causes hyporeflexia and does not cause hypertension, elevated temperature, dry skin, or mydriasis.
questions.hint: The symptoms of anticholinergic syndrome can be remembered as: "Blind as a bat (mydriasis), mad as a hatter (delirium), red as a beet (flushing), hot as a hare (hyperthermia), dry as a bone (decreased secretions and dry skin), the bowel and bladder lose their tone (urinary retention and paralytic ileus), and the heart runs alone (tachycardia).”

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary incontinence. The urge to urinate occurs suddenly, and he often is unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. He has no incontinence with coughing or laughing. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a normal post-void residual volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxazosin, an alpha-1 antagonist that causes relaxation of the bladder sphincter muscle, is used in the treatment of urinary retention and concomitant overflow incontinence due to an overactive sphincter or BPH. A normal post-void residual volume makes urinary retention unlikely in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence has an overactive bladder with heightened detrusor tone; relaxation of the urinary sphincter could worsen his symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Bethanechol, a parasympathomimetic agent, is used in the treatment of urinary retention and concomitant overflow incontinence due to an underactive detrusor, which can occasionally occur in patients with multiple sclerosis due to lesions below S1 spinal level. A normal post-void residual volume makes urinary retention unlikely in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence has an overactive bladder with heightened detrusor tone; increasing it further would likely worsen his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Midodrine, an alpha-1 agonist that causes contraction of the urinary sphincter and detrusor, is used in the treatment of underactive bladder sphincter (stress incontinence), which can occur in patients with multiple sclerosis due to demyelinating lesions below S1 spinal level. However, stress incontinence presents with dribbling of urine during laughing or coughing, which is not reported in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence already has a heightened detrusor tone; increasing it further would likely worsen his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that affects the central nervous system (CNS) and is used in the treatment of dementia. Rivastigmine is not used to treat urinary incontinence.

E) INCORRECT:

Mirtazapine, an alpha-2 antagonist, is used to treat depression, which often occurs in patients with multiple sclerosis. However, mirtazapine is not used to treat urinary incontinence because alpha-2 adrenergic receptors do not play a role in maintaining urinary continence. An alpha-1 antagonist can be used to treat certain forms of urinary incontinence.

F) CORRECT:

In a healthy individual, bladder wall relaxation due to stimulation of β3 receptors in the detrusor muscle allows storage of urine. During the storage phase, contraction of the trigone and sphincter muscles due to stimulation of α1 receptors at these sites maintains continence. Bladder wall contraction due to stimulation of M3 receptors in the detrusor muscle, and reflex inhibition of the trigone and sphincter allows for micturition to occur during the voiding phase. Muscarinic antagonists (e.g. tolterodine, oxybutynin, solifenacin, dicyclomine) and the newly developed β3 agonists (e.g., mirabegron) relax detrusor muscles, and can therefore be used to treat urge incontinence caused by an overactive detrusor muscle.
questions.hint: In a patient with multiple sclerosis, a sudden urge to urinate that is not related to increased intra-abdominal pressure is consistent with urge incontinence due to detrusor hyperreflexia (upper motor neuron dysfunction!).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 30-minute history of dizziness and shortness of breath. After establishing the diagnosis, treatment with a drug is administered. Shortly after administration, the patient develops severe left eye pain and decreased vision of the left eye, along with nausea and vomiting. Ophthalmologic examination shows a fixed, mid-dilated pupil and a narrowed anterior chamber of the left eye. The patient was most likely treated for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient was most likely treated for atrioventricular block (AV block), which can manifest with shortness of breath and dizziness. Atropine (a muscarinic antagonist) is used to increase the heart rate in AV block due to its ability to reduce the effects of the parasympathetic nervous system on the SA node and the AV node. In the eye, atropine causes pupillary dilatation, which can result in narrowing of the anterior chamber angle and obstructed flow of aqueous humor between the posterior and anterior chamber, potentially leading to acute angle-closure glaucoma.
Image Description:

Cross-section of the anterior portion of the eye

Pressure rises in the posterior chamber if the flow of aqueous humor from the posterior to the anterior chamber is obstructed due to a functional block (pupillary block) between the lens and the pupillary portion of the iris. This increase in pressure causes the peripheral portion of the iris to move anteriorly and to cover parts or all of the chamber angle (particularly in mydriasis or mid-dilation), potentially leading to acute angle-closure with massively increased intraocular pressure. In certain anatomical variants (e.g., shallow anterior chamber), the chamber angle is already narrow and therefore increases the probability of acute and/or chronic angle-closure, which can lead to damage of the optic nerve (glaucoma).

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive crisis may present with dizziness and shortness of breath. However, the drugs used in its management (mainly nitrates, calcium channel blockers) are not associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation could explain this patient's symptoms of shortness of breath and dizziness. However, drugs used in the management of atrial fibrillation such as beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin, and anticoagulants are not associated with acute angle-closure glaucoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation could explain this patient's symptoms of dizziness and shortness of breath. Depending on the degree of LV dysfunction it is either treated conservatively or surgically (valve repair or replacement). Acute mitral regurgitation is an emergency in which diuretics, nitrates, and antihypertensive drugs are used to stabilize the patient. None of these drugs are commonly associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

E) INCORRECT:

While a pulmonary embolism could explain the patient's initial presenting symptoms of dizziness and shortness of breath, non-invasive treatment usually consists of O2, analgesics (e.g. NSAIDs), and heparin, none of which is commonly associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Pleuritis is an inflammation of the pleura that lines the lungs and is commonly caused by viral infection. It usually presents with a sharp chest pain that worsens with inhalation, but shortness of breath and dizziness are rare. Viral pleuritis is usually managed with analgesic drugs, e.g. NSAIDs, which do not precipitate angle-closure glaucoma.
questions.hint: The patient's severe eye pain, fixed, mid-dilated pupil, and narrowed anterior chamber on examination are suggestive of acute angle closure glaucoma, which can be precipitated by muscarinic antagonists.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased sweating for the past 6 months. She experiences severe sweating that is triggered by stressful situations and speaking in public. She is failing one of her university classes because of her avoidance of public speaking. She has not had any fevers, chills, weight loss, or night sweats. Her temperature is 36.6°C (98°F). Physical examination shows moist skin in the axillae and on the palms, soles, and face. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pilocarpine is a direct parasympathomimetic (direct agonist) that binds directly to muscarinic ACh receptors, which in turn increases the secretion of sweat. Pilocarpine would worsen this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin stimulates uterine contractions and milk expression. It does not play a role in sweat gland secretion and would have no effect on this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine is an indirect parasympathomimetic (indirect agonist) that decreases the breakdown of ACh, which in turn increases the secretion of sweat. Physostigmine would worsen this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic agent that mainly affects α-1 adrenergic receptors, causing vasoconstriction, nasal decongestion, and mydriasis. It does not play a role in sweat gland secretion and would have no effect on this patient's condition.

E) CORRECT:

Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent used to treat hyperhidrosis. This drug blocks ACh at muscarinic receptors, which temporarily reduces sweat production. As with any anticholinergic drug, careful dosing is required to avoid adverse effects of excessive ACh inhibition (e.g., flushed skin, cycloplegia, dry mouth, constipation).

Botulinum toxin, which also inhibits ACh release, can be used to treat focal hyperhidrosis (e.g., hyperhidrosis limited to the axillae).
questions.hint: Sweating is an autonomic reflex primarily mediated by acetylcholine receptors of the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of agitation and confusion for the past hour. The parents say they found him in their room next to an empty bottle of pills, picking at the air as if to grab something. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His father has hypertension and his mother has allergic rhinitis. He appears anxious. Temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), respirations are 20/min, pulse is 126/min, and blood pressure is 119/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, dry skin and dry mucous membranes. On mental status examination, he is combative, confused, and disoriented. The pupils are dilated. Serum glucose concentration is normal. Urine toxicology screening is negative. ECG shows sinus tachycardia and no other abnormalities. In addition to supportive care, monitoring, and activated charcoal administration, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine can be used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), a condition that commonly manifests with hyperthermia, altered mental status, and tachycardia. This patient, however, lacks other symptoms of NMS, like muscle rigidity, akinesia, and tremor. Moreover, there is no evidence to suggest availability of drugs that precipitate NMS (e.g., antipsychotics, certain anti-emetics).

B) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is used for the treatment of malignant hyperthermia (MH), which typically manifests with hyperthermia and sinus tachycardia. This young boy, however, lacks other features of MH, such as rigidity, tachypnea, and cyanosis (early signs of MH) or secondary organ damage (late signs of MH). Hallucinations, mydriasis, and warm, dry skin and mucous membranes, are not consistent with MH. Finally, there is no history of volatile anesthetic use, making MH unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is indicated in the treatment of serotonin syndrome. Hyperthermia, altered mental status, hallucinations, agitation, and tachycardia are all typical of this condition. However, patients with serotonin syndrome also tend to have neuromuscular excitability (e.g., clonus), diaphoresis, and autonomic dysfunction. Also, this patient has no history of ingesting drugs that increase serotonin levels (e.g., psychiatric drugs, tramadol, ondansetron). Instead, it is more likely he consumed his mother's antihistamines.

D) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used as an antidote for opioid intoxication, which causes altered mental status. However, this condition typically manifests with respiratory depression, miosis (not mydriasis), bradycardia (not tachycardia), and hypothermia (not fever). Moreover, there is no evidence to suggest opioid availability in the patient's home; this child most likely ingested his mother's antihistamines, given her history of allergic rhinitis.

E) CORRECT:

Physostigmine is the antidote for pure anticholinergic poisoning. Because physostigmine is lipophilic, it is able to cross the blood-brain barrier and reverse the signs and symptoms of central poisoning (confusion, agitation, aggressiveness, hallucinations). Use of physostigmine is usually only warranted in cases in which pure anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., overdose with atropine, benztropine) is suspected but can be considered in patients with anticholinergic poisoning due to other agents (e.g., antihistamines) if they present with features of severe central anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., delirium). Physostigmine should be avoided in patients with tricyclic antidepressant overdose because of the risk of cardiac arrest. Physostigmine should be carefully administered and patients should be monitored for cholinergic toxicity.
questions.hint: "Blind as a bat (mydriasis), mad as a hatter (delirium & hallucinations), red as a beet (flushing), hot as a hare (hyperthermia), dry as a bone (decreased secretions and dry skin), the bowel and bladder lose their tone (urinary retention and paralytic ileus), and the heart runs alone (tachycardia).” This patient most likely developed anticholinergic syndrome after ingesting his mother's antihistamines for allergic rhinitis.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and urge incontinence presents for her annual wellness visit. During the past year, she was started on linagliptin for her diabetes, which was not controlled with metformin alone. Her most recent glycated hemoglobin level was 7.8% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). For the urge incontinence, she was started on extended-release oxybutynin 10 mg daily four months ago and has also been restricting her fluid intake to around 1.5 liters per day. She takes no other medications.
Today, her main concern is worsening dry eyes, which she finds bothersome and believes to be affecting her vision, and dry mouth. She also reports worsening constipation, with only one bowel movement every 2 to 3 days; her stools are hard but there is no blood, and she has no other gastrointestinal symptoms.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Stop oxybutynin, and recommend pelvic physical therapy
Counsel her that symptoms can be expected to improve gradually
Continue current management, but recommend artificial tears and a stimulant laxative

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s dry eyes, dry mouth, and constipation are typical anticholinergic symptoms, most likely caused by recent initiation of oxybutynin. Anticholinergic medications can also contribute to falls, delirium, and cognitive impairment. These effects are more pronounced in older adults and are not expected to improve without discontinuing the medication or decreasing the dose. In this case, the patient is already taking a very low dose of oxybutynin, so a dose reduction is not possible. The most appropriate next step is to stop the oxybutynin and recommend other interventions for her urge incontinence, such as pelvic physical therapy. Other urinary agents, such as mirabegron, may provide symptomatic relief without adverse anticholinergic effects.

Treating the adverse effects of oxybutynin with additional medications, such as artificial tears or a laxative regimen, would increase polypharmacy and thus increase the likelihood of additional adverse effects and drug interactions. A better approach is to stop use of the causative agent and avoid a prescribing cascade, where a new medication is added to treat the adverse effect of another agent.

Key learning point: The adverse effects of anticholinergic medications are more common in older patients and are not likely to improve without discontinuation of the medication.

B) INCORRECT:

These effects are more pronounced in older adults and are not expected to improve without discontinuing the medication or decreasing the dose.

C) INCORRECT:

Switching this patient’s antidiabetic agent to semaglutide could be considered if her glycemic control was inadequate, but her glycated hemoglobin concentration (7.8%) is reasonable for a person her age; glycated hemoglobin targets as high as 8% to 8.5% may be appropriate for older adults, depending on their coexisting chronic illnesses, functional status, and cognitive function. In addition, this patient’s glycated hemoglobin concentration suggests that glycosuria is unlikely to be a primary driver of her urinary symptoms. Finally, it should be noted that semaglutide can cause constipation, so if a switch were being considered in this patient, it would not be advisable until the adverse effects of the oxybutynin had resolved.

D) INCORRECT:

Treating the adverse effects of oxybutynin with additional medications, such as artificial tears or a laxative regimen, would increase polypharmacy and thus increase the likelihood of additional adverse effects and drug interactions. A better approach is to stop use of the causative agent and avoid a prescribing cascade, where a new medication is added to treat the adverse effect of another agent.

E) INCORRECT:

Although increasing this patient’s fluid intake could help with her dry mouth and constipation, it would probably worsen her urinary symptoms and would not address the other anticholinergic adverse effects of oxybutynin.

questions.text:
A 22-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department (ED) with increasing somnolence, altered mental status, and tachycardia. His mother reports that she had left him in her bedroom for about 90 minutes for a nap, and when she went to check on him, he was lying on the floor with her over-the-counter sleep-aid gel capsules scattered around him. She immediately called emergency medical services and checked his mouth but did not find any objects or capsule remnants there. She thinks there were initially 10 capsules in the bottle but could find only four; she has no other medications in the home. The patient has no significant medical history and is up to date with his immunizations.
On physical examination in the ED, he has a temperature of 38.3°C, a heart rate of 157 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 101/67 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. He has intermittent episodes of irritability, confusion, and mild agitation. His pupils are equal in size (5 mm) and slow to react. He has no heart murmurs, his lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and nontender with slowed bowel sounds. He has no signs of trauma, and his skin feels warm and dry.
An electrocardiogram identifies sinus tachycardia with a QRS duration of 76 msec and a corrected QT interval of 440 msec. A point-of-care fingerstick test shows a serum glucose level of 111 mg/dL (60–100).
A peripheral intravenous line is inserted, and the patient is placed on a continuous cardiovascular-respiratory monitor.
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s toxidrome?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When a patient ingests only a relatively small amount of a first-generation antihistamine and does not experience significant adverse effects, management involves only supportive care. Activated charcoal is reserved for patients with normal mentation and is indicated within one hour after the ingestion.

B) INCORRECT:

Antidotal therapy with physostigmine can be used when a patient develops severe symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., severe agitation, significant self-injurious behaviors, or bronchospasm). Physostigmine is a carbamate acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that reversibly binds acetylcholinesterase, increasing acetylcholine at the muscarinic receptors to overcome receptor blockade and relieve associated symptoms. However, its adverse effects and contraindications preclude routine use, and consultation with a medical toxicologist is recommended before administering this agent.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is irritable, confused, and mildly agitated, with low-grade fever, tachycardia, mydriasis, dry skin, and hypoactive bowel sounds in the setting of a medication ingestion. These symptoms are consistent with an anticholinergic toxidrome, which is described by the mnemonic “mad as a hatter, blind as a bat, hot as a hare, red as a beet, and dry as a bone.” Several drugs and toxins can cause this toxidrome, including atropine, scopolamine, first-generation antihistamines, tricyclic antidepressants, carbamazepine, and jimson weed. In this case, the most likely culprit is the first-generation antihistamine diphenhydramine, which is an active ingredient in many over-the-counter sleep aids.

First-generation antihistamines can act on the central nervous system (CNS) H1 receptors to cause altered mental status and hallucinations. In severe unintentional or intentional overdoses, ingestion of these agents can lead to seizures, coma, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrhythmias. In this case, the patient is experiencing CNS effects (agitation and confusion), and his heart rate is elevated, but he has a normal QRS duration and a normal corrected QT interval on electrocardiogram.

When a patient ingests only a relatively small amount of a first-generation antihistamine and does not experience significant adverse effects, management involves only supportive care. Activated charcoal is reserved for patients with normal mentation and is indicated within one hour after the ingestion.

When agitation or other, more mild symptoms are present (as in this case), a benzodiazepine should be considered; this class of medications is safe and effective and can be used in high doses to alleviate symptoms.

Key learning point: For mild agitation and altered mental status associated with an acute anticholinergic toxidrome, appropriate management includes clinical monitoring, intravenous fluids, and benzodiazepines as needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Antipyretics and other cooling measures can be used to treat hyperthermia and temperature instability associated with anticholinergic poisoning, but these interventions would not take precedence over a benzodiazepine or other supportive measures for this patient’s symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Sodium bicarbonate is indicated to treat anticholinergic-induced arrhythmias when the QRS interval on serial electrocardiograms (ECGs) is either widened (>100) or widening. This patient’s normal QRS interval does not mandate this therapeutic intervention at this time, but serial ECGs should be included in his clinical monitoring.

questions.text: You are caring for a 31-year-old man who was hospitalized two days ago for substance-induced psychosis. He has developed episodic neck stiffness and pain over the past 8 hours. Each episode lasts about 25 minutes and is associated with his neck rotating to the right. He reports that during the last episode, he was able to relieve the stiffness by lightly touching his jaw. He has received six doses of haloperidol for auditory hallucinations since admission. His temperature is 37.3°C, pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. On examination, his neck is flexed and rotated to the right, with rigidity and limited range of motion. Which one of the following is the most appropriate therapy for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Baclofen is a GABA receptor agonist commonly used as a muscle relaxant to treat spasticity. However, it shows little effect in the treatment of secondary dystonia (e.g., medication-induced acute dystonia) and would only be indicated after other preferred treatments have failed. Baclofen is usually used for treating primary dystonia (idiopathic, hereditary) and is more effective in children and adolescents than in adults.

B) CORRECT:

Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia manifests with painful torticollis (as seen here), opisthotonus, oculogyric crisis, trismus, tongue spasm, and/or laryngospasm. Risk factors include male sex and young age. This condition's pathophysiology is incompletely understood but an imbalance between dopaminergic activity in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia (due to D2 receptor antagonism by the antipsychotic) and cholinergic transmission in the striatum is thought to play a role. A centrally acting anticholinergic drug such as benztropine or diphenhydramine is the first-line treatment for neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia (see “Overview of extrapyramidal symptoms” table).

The role of cholinergic transmission in the pathophysiology of neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia is also supported by the observation that the risk of acute dystonia is lower with low-potency typical antipsychotics, which have an anticholinergic effect and a weaker antidopaminergic effect when compared with high-potency typical antipsychotics.

Key learning point: Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia is best treated with centrally acting anticholinergic agents such as benztropine or diphenhydramine.

C) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy can be used as an adjunctive treatment for this patient's condition. However, highly effective, well-tolerated pharmacotherapy would be the first-line intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the first-line treatment for akathisia, which is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic drugs. While this patient is at risk for akathisia, it is characterized by restlessness, fidgeting, and/or pacing. Instead, this patient's cervical muscle spasms are characteristic of another extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant used to treat malignant hyperthermia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and (severe) chronic spasticity resulting from upper motor neuron damage (e.g., stroke, multiple sclerosis). Although the patient suffers from spasticity in his neck, the condition is acute and not chronic. In addition, since dantrolene may also cause psychiatric side effects (e.g., depression, confusion, insomnia), it should be given with caution in patients with a history of psychiatric symptoms.
questions.hint: The repeated episodes of painful neck stiffness are suggestive of acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect that typically occurs within a few days of initiating or increasing the dose of a high-potency typical antipsychotic (e.g., haloperidol).

questions.text: You are seeing a 30-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his sister because of progressive drowsiness and confusion over the past 6 hours. He is lethargic and unable to answer questions. His sister reports a history of illicit drug use. His temperature is 38°C, pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. On examination, his skin is warm and dry, and his mucous membranes are dry. His pupils are dilated. The abdomen is distended with hypoactive bowel sounds. Laboratory studies are within reference ranges. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Intoxication with which one of the following substances is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cocaine intoxication may cause mydriasis and tachycardia. However, the condition usually manifests with agitation and diaphoresis, as opposed to the sedation and dry skin seen in this patient. Other findings typically seen in cocaine intoxication, such as hypertension, are absent.

B) INCORRECT:

Opioid intoxication may lead to altered mental status, which is consistent with this patient's confusion and sedation. Additionally, opioid intoxication can manifest with hypoactive bowel sounds. However, opioid toxicity causes miosis rather than mydriasis. Moreover, other findings commonly seen in opioid intoxication, such as respiratory depression, are absent.

C) INCORRECT:

Cannabis intoxication can manifest with mild tachycardia, dry mouth, and mydriasis with conjunctival injection. However, other typical findings, such as hyperemesis, dysphoria, anxiety, panic, and increased blood pressure are absent in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is characteristic of antihistamine toxicity, which is most commonly caused by an overdose of first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine). The CNS effects of sedation and confusion are mediated by H1 histamine receptors, while dry skin, dry mucous membranes, mydriasis, hyperthermia, tachycardia, and reduced bowel sounds are due to anticholinergic effects. Further complications of antihistamine toxicity include cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and seizures. Management includes close monitoring, supportive therapy, and, in severe cases, administration of an anticholinergic antidote.

Second-generation antihistamines have less of a sedative effect than first-generation antihistamines because of their limited CNS activity.

Key learning point: Antihistamine toxicity presents with anticholinergic symptoms such as confusion, sedation, mydriasis, dry skin and mucous membranes, tachycardia, and decreased bowel sounds.

E) INCORRECT:

Amphetamine intoxication can manifest with constipation, mydriasis, and tachycardia. While severe cases of amphetamine toxicity may cause coma, patients are usually agitated or psychotic. Additionally, the condition usually manifests with diaphoresis, as opposed to the dry skin seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient should be treated with physostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of urinary leakage over the past year. She reports involuntarily losing small amounts of urine after experiencing a sudden need to void. She has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time, and only feels comfortable going out into public if she has documented the location of all nearby restrooms. She also has begun to wake up at night to urinate. These symptoms have persisted despite 6 months of bladder training and weight loss, and reducing soda and coffee intake. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely to be effective in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antimuscarinic agents such as oxybutynin antagonize parasympathetic muscarinic M3 receptors found in the bladder. Muscarinic M3 receptor stimulation is responsible for bladder contraction; thus, inhibition leads to improvement of symptoms in patients with urge incontinence. Pharmacotherapy should be reserved as an additional therapeutic option for patients in which behavioral therapy and lifestyle modifications alone were insufficient. Because muscarinic M3 receptors are located in various glands and in smooth muscles, anticholinergic agents have several systemic side effects, including pupillary dilation, dry mouth, constipation, tachycardia, and impaired cognition. They should be used with caution in patients predisposed to delirium (e.g., elderly patients). Beta-3 agonists, such as mirabegron, can be used to treat urge incontinence in patients who do not tolerate or have contraindications to antimuscarinic therapy.

See “Overview of sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system receptors” table.
Image Description:

Depicted here are the subtypes of adrenergic receptors (α and β) and cholinergic receptors (M: muscarinic, N: nicotinic), which trigger the organ response described when activated. The sympathetic chain is represented by the yellow chain of ganglia to the left of the spinal cord. Also depicted are cranial nerves (CN III, VII, IX, X) emerging from the brainstem.

B) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antagonists such as tamsulosin are commonly prescribed to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia, a condition that may cause overflow incontinence secondary to urinary retention in men. Antagonism of this receptor causes relaxation of the bladder neck muscles. In patients with urge incontinence due to detrusor overactivity, relaxation of the bladder neck muscles would likely worsen symptoms as there would be no resistance to counteract bladder contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of beta-3 adrenergic receptors found on smooth muscle cells of the urinary bladder promotes detrusor muscle relaxation, thereby delaying the need for micturition. Antagonism of these receptors would cause increased detrusor contraction and would worsen symptoms in patients with urge incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

While beta-2 agonism would cause detrusor muscle relaxation of the bladder, it is not commonly used to treat urge incontinence. Beta-2 adrenergic agonists (e.g., albuterol or salmeterol) are used to manage asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, as they are very potent bronchodilators.

E) INCORRECT:

Agonism of muscarinic M3 receptors causes bladder contraction. Drugs such as bethanechol stimulate expulsion of urine and are commonly used for patients with overflow urinary incontinence. Unlike urge incontinence, overflow incontinence usually causes continuous dribbling and is not typically associated with a sudden urge to void.

F) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic receptor antagonists such as rocuronium are primarily used as muscle relaxants intraoperatively. Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are found in presynaptic neurons of the autonomic ganglia, and postsynaptic neurons of the neuromuscular junction of skeletal muscles. Bladder contraction is regulated by smooth muscle, not skeletal muscle; so drugs affecting the nicotinic receptor pathway would not be effective at improving symptoms of urge incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent involuntary loss of small amounts of urine and nocturia. Because she has failed conservative treatment, she qualifies for pharmacologic treatment. Oxybutynin would be an appropriate first-line medication.
